The fluorescent lights of the concrete room cast a sickly, greenish pallor over everything, stripping the colour from Finn’s cashmere jumper and the life from his face. He was sitting on a hard plastic chair, his hands bound behind his back, his eyes wide with a terror that was utterly devoid of his usual theatricality. This was real. Behind him, the thuggish man stood impassively, a solid wall of brute force, his presence a guarantee of the violence that was being held in reserve. The video had no sound, which made it worse. Finn’s mouth moved, forming words she couldn’t hear, a silent, desperate plea that struck Moira with the force of a physical blow. The air rushed from her lungs. The floor, the walls, the entire world seemed to tilt on its axis, and the only point of stability was her uncle’s cold, triumphant face.

Alistair’s voice was soft, almost gentle, a caress of steel against her throat. "As you can see, he is being well looked after. For now. The equation is a simple one, Moira. A matter of balancing the books, something you’ve always understood. You have an asset that I require. I have an asset that, I presume, you value. I am proposing a simple exchange. Your compliance for his continued well-being." He lowered the phone, pocketing it with a sense of finality, robbing her of even the horrifying image of her friend. He had shown her the knife; now he was letting her imagination do the rest of the work. The choice was a vise, crushing her from two sides. On one side, Finn, her only real family, the man who had brought colour and laughter into her grey world, his life hanging by the thread of her obedience. On the other, Rajan, the embodiment of her rebellion, the soul of her newfound life, his existence now the price of her friend’s freedom. To save one was to condemn the other.

"You bastard," she whispered, the words small and useless against the sheer scale of his cruelty. "You absolute bastard." Alistair sighed, a sound of profound disappointment. "Please, Moira, let us not descend into vulgarity. This is not personal. It is business. You made a foolish, sentimental move, and it has had consequences. I am merely managing those consequences. Now, my men are downstairs. They have the large transportation crate. They will bring it up, and you will assist in securing the animal for removal. It is all quite straightforward." From the spare room, a deep growl rumbled through the floorboards, a low, questioning note of unease. Rajan could feel the shift in the room's atmosphere, the sharp, acidic tang of Moira’s fear, the cold, predatory aura of the other man. The sound was a visceral reminder of what Alistair was demanding she sacrifice. It was the sound of the wild, the sound of her soul, and he was asking her to cage it and hand it over.

The accountant in her screamed that there was no choice. The survival of a human life outweighed all other considerations. The ledger was brutally clear on this point. Finn was a tangible, quantifiable priority. But the rebel, the woman who had tasted a life beyond quantifiable truths, screamed back. To surrender Rajan was to surrender everything, to admit that her brief, glorious flight had been nothing more than a folly, to hand the keys to her soul back to the man who wanted to cage it. It would be a spiritual death, and she would have to live with the ghost of it for the rest of her days. She looked at her uncle, at the calm, implacable certainty on his face. He saw this as a simple transaction. He understood assets and liabilities, debits and credits. And in that moment, in the depths of her despair, a new path began to form, a desperate, terrifying gambit born of his own cold logic. She could not fight him with passion. She had to fight him with numbers.

She straightened her shoulders, the movement small but deliberate. She lifted her chin and met his gaze, her expression shifting from one of horrified grief to one of cold, hard negotiation. The sudden change in her demeanour seemed to surprise him, his eyebrows rising a fraction of an inch. "A transaction," she said, her voice devoid of emotion, a perfect imitation of his own. "Very well. But every transaction has terms. You don't just hand over an asset of this value without due diligence and proof of reciprocation." Alistair’s lips twitched in a semblance of a smile. He was intrigued. The rabbit was not just refusing to bolt; it was asking to see the fine print on the snare. "Go on," he said, a note of academic interest in his voice.

"I have two conditions," Moira stated, her voice gaining strength. "First, proof of life. Not a silent video. I want to speak to him. Now. I want to hear his voice, and I want him to confirm a piece of information only he would know. A security question." Alistair considered this for a moment. A minor, sentimental request, but a deviation from his plan. He gave a slight nod. "Reasonable. And your second condition?" This was the true gamble, the move that would either buy her the time she needed or expose her hand completely. "The exchange does not happen here," she said firmly. "Moving an animal of this size and temperament is a complex logistical operation. This building, this stairwell... it is not secure. We tried to move a freezer yesterday and almost brought the landing down. It's a high-risk environment. I will not be responsible for the asset being harmed, or for it harming one of your men, during a poorly planned extraction."

She was speaking his language now. Risk mitigation. Asset protection. Liability. She could see the calculations turning over in his mind. He had planned a swift, brutal extraction, a show of force. She was offering a more efficient, professional alternative. "Where, then?" he asked, the hook baited. "The lock-up in Anniesland," she said, the words coming quickly, the plan forming even as she spoke it. "The one where I kept the crate. It's on the ground floor. It's secure. It's private. You can bring your vehicle right up to the door. We move him there, under my supervision, to ensure his welfare. Once he is securely transferred from my crate to your transportation, and I have visual confirmation that Finn is safe and on his way home, the transaction is complete."

It was a brilliant deception, wrapped in the language of pragmatic cooperation. She was changing the venue, taking the war to a territory of her own choosing, buying herself hours instead of minutes, and creating a dozen new logistical variables that she might, just might, be able to exploit. Alistair was silent for a long, heavy moment, his pale blue eyes boring into her, searching for the flaw, the trick. But her logic was sound, her reasoning framed entirely in terms of his own priorities. She wasn't fighting him; she was helping him be more efficient. "Very well," he said at last, the decision made. "Your prudence is... noted. We will proceed at the Anniesland location." He took out his phone again. "First, your proof of life." He dialled, and put the phone on speaker. It rang once. A gruff voice answered. "Yes." "Put him on," Alistair commanded.

There was a muffled sound, and then Finn’s voice, shaky and terrified, filled the room. "Moira? Oh god, Moira, are you there?" "I'm here, Finn," she said, her voice catching for the first time. "Are you hurt?" "No, no, I'm just... Moira, whatever he wants, just give it to him—" Alistair cut him off. "Your security question, Moira. Be quick." She closed her eyes, searching for a piece of their shared life, a private joke, a memory. "Finn," she said, her voice clear and steady. "What was the name of the abysmal, one-eyed cat we fostered a decade ago? The one that hated everyone but you." There was a pause, a shaky breath, and then Finn’s voice, a flicker of his old self cutting through the fear. "Captain Winky," he whispered. "His name was Captain Winky." It was enough. "He's alive," Moira said to Alistair, her voice flat. "The exchange will take place at the lock-up. At noon."

Alistair nodded, satisfied. The deal was struck. He turned away from her, already speaking into his phone, issuing a rapid-fire series of commands to his men, rearranging logistics, diverting vehicles, his mind now focused on the new, more efficient plan she had so helpfully provided. He had won. He was getting his asset back, and his troublesome niece had finally been brought to heel. Moira watched him, her face a mask of cold, defeated compliance. But behind the mask, her mind was a firestorm of frantic, beautiful, and utterly terrifying calculation. He thought he was moving a tiger. But Moira MacLeod, accountant and rebel, was about to balance a ledger with the only currency she had left: absolute, glorious chaos.The silence Alistair left behind was a vacuum, pulling at the very air in the room, threatening to implode. But where there is a vacuum, something must rush in to fill it. In Moira’s case, it was a cold, pure, calculating rage that was as clear and bright as a diamond. He had made a fatal error, the kind of mistake arrogant men always make: he had shown her his entire hand, assuming she had no cards left to play. He had given her his logic, his methodology, and his assets. And now she was going to use them to burn his entire enterprise to the ground. She did not panic. Panic was a luxury, a debit on the emotional ledger she could not afford. Instead, she walked to the kitchen, her movements fluid and economical, and put the kettle on for a third time that morning. While the water heated, she took out a notepad and a pen. The accountant was back in her element, not balancing books, but unbalancing a tyrant.

Under the heading ‘OPERATION: LIQUIDATION’, she began to write. The plan was insane, a fantasy woven from desperation and adrenaline, but it had a structure, a terrible, logical beauty that the old Moira would have admired. It had three phases. Phase One: Asset Extraction and Relocation. Phase Two: The Decoy. Phase Three: Calculated Chaos and Extraction of Personnel. She had less than two hours. Time was her most pressing liability. Her first call was not to Finn, who was a compromised party, but to a number saved in her phone under ‘Butcher’. A gruff, sleepy voice answered on the third ring. “Davies’ Meats.”

“Mr. Davies,” Moira said, her voice a pitch-perfect imitation of a frantic but professional catering manager. “Moira MacLeod here. I have a crisis, and I need your immediate assistance. I have a last-minute, extremely high-value consignment for the Blackwood Estate contract.” She had invented the Blackwood Estate contract weeks ago as a cover for her bulk chicken orders. “It’s… game. Very rare. Very temperature-sensitive. The problem is, a competing firm is attempting a hostile takeover of my route. I need to move the consignment to a secure secondary location before they intercept it. I need your largest refrigerated van, and your most discreet driver. At the Anniesland industrial estate. In thirty minutes. The remuneration for this emergency service will be… substantial.” There was a pause on the other end, filled with the sound of a man mentally calculating profit margins against Sunday morning inconvenience. “Hostile takeover, eh?” Mr. Davies grunted. “Happened to me in ’98 with the pork pie consortium. Cut-throat business. My lad can be there in forty minutes. Cash on delivery for the van hire, mind.” “Of course,” Moira said, relief a brief, warm flicker. "Tell him to look for a white Luton van at unit 17. And Mr. Davies? Discretion is everything.”

Phase One was a brutal, desperate replay of the descent she had performed with Finn, but compressed into a frantic twenty minutes and conducted in the blue-grey twilight of dawn. This time, there was no fear of Mr. Henderson. The only surveillance she feared was the possibility of one of Alistair’s men watching the building. She had to assume they were. This meant the Luton van, her Trojan horse, had to remain parked and silent. The descent was a nightmare of screaming muscles and frayed ropes. She guided the crate down the stairwell alone, her body aching in protest, her breath coming in ragged, painful gasps. The scrape of metal on plaster was a gunshot in the silent tenement. She did not have the strength to use the block and tackle; instead, she used gravity, friction, and sheer bloody-minded will, letting the crate slide and bump down the steps under the precarious control of the ropes wrapped around her raw hands.

When she reached the bottom, bruised and trembling, she opened the crate. Rajan, who had endured the clumsy, jarring descent with a tense, rumbling patience, looked out at her. She did not try to trick him or command him. She just looked at him, her heart in her eyes, a silent plea. He held her gaze for a long moment, then he padded out of the crate and, with a flick of his tail, leaped silently into the back of the waiting Luton van, which she had opened in readiness. He coiled himself in the dark, cavernous space, a hidden power waiting for its cue. The transaction of trust had been re-established. Working with a speed she didn’t know she possessed, she wrestled the now-empty crate back up one flight of stairs and left it on the first-floor landing, a discarded shell. Then she climbed into the cab of the van, started the engine, and pulled away from Hyndland Street. In the rearview mirror, she saw a dark saloon car parked half a street away, its engine off. It did not follow. They assumed she was making a panicked, foolish run for it. They would be tracking her phone, which she had deliberately left behind in her flat. They thought they knew where she was. Let them.

The Anniesland industrial estate was a ghost town of corrugated steel and chain-link fences. Rain fell in a steady, miserable drizzle, turning the potholed tarmac into a slick of black glass. Mr. Davies’ lad, a burly young man with a face devoid of curiosity, was waiting as promised, parked beside unit 17. His refrigerated van was old and battered, its ‘Davies’ Meats’ logo half-peeled from the side, but its engine hummed with a reliable thrum. The exchange was brief and professional. Moira paid the exorbitant cash fee without flinching and took the keys. The young man got into a waiting car and disappeared, leaving Moira alone with two vans, a tiger, and a plan that felt thinner than tracing paper in the face of the oncoming storm.

She worked quickly, backing the butcher’s van up to the roller door of the lock-up. Then, with her heart in her mouth, she opened the back of the Luton van. Rajan was a pool of coiled energy in the darkness. "Come on, my boy," she whispered. "Just one more move." He rose, stretched, and with the fluid grace of a creature made of shadow and muscle, he leaped from the Luton van and padded into the dark, cold interior of the lock-up garage. She slid the heavy steel door down, entombing him inside, and took a moment to lean against the cold metal, her entire body trembling with exertion and fear. Phase Two: The Decoy. She maneuvered the Luton van, now empty save for its ghost of a tiger-scent, and parked it directly in front of the lock-up door, its rear doors facing outward, as if ready for a transfer. It was a stage, perfectly set for an audience that expected a tragedy and would get a farce. Then she moved the butcher’s van, her escape vehicle, to the far side of the building, out of sight, a secret held by the rain and the industrial grime.

She had just finished when the convoy arrived. It was not a car; it was a procession. Two black Range Rovers, their windows tinted to an absolute, menacing darkness, and a larger, windowless black truck that was clearly a bespoke animal transport unit. They moved with a silent, predatory grace, boxing in the battered white Luton van. Alistair did not get out. The rear door of the lead Range Rover slid open, and two of his grey-suited men emerged, their movements precise and coordinated. At the same time, the passenger door of the second vehicle opened, and Finn was unceremoniously pushed out. He stumbled, regained his balance, and saw Moira standing by the lock-up. He broke into a frantic, limping run, his face a mess of relief and terror.

"Moira! What are you doing? They're going to—" "Get in the van, Finn!" she screamed, pointing towards the hidden butcher’s van. "Get in and don't look back!" Alistair’s men were moving now, ignoring the spectacle of the reunion, their focus entirely on the objective. They marched to the rear of the Luton van, ready to open it and secure what they believed was inside. This was the moment. The pivot point on which her entire world would turn. As Finn scrambled past her, fumbling with the door of the escape van, Moira took a deep breath, turned her back on her uncle's men, and faced the heavy steel roller door of the lock-up. In her hand, she held the simple metal latch. She did not hesitate. With a single, decisive movement, she yanked it upwards. The door shot up with a deafening, metallic roar, revealing the dark cavern of the garage within. From the darkness, two burning amber eyes blinked in the sudden light, and a low, guttural growl echoed out into the rain-soaked air, a sound of pure, carnivorous life finally unleashed. She had just opened the cage. Absolute, glorious chaos had begun.The sound that erupted from the dark mouth of the lock-up was not a growl. It was a geological event. It was a full-throated, primal roar that tore through the rain-soaked air, a sound so deep and powerful it seemed to vibrate in the fillings of Moira’s teeth. The industrial estate, a place of mundane mechanics and diesel fumes, was momentarily silenced, the patter of rain and the hum of engines utterly vanquished by a noise that belonged to the Pleistocene epoch. For a frozen second, everything stopped. The two grey-suited men, who had been moving with the fluid assurance of apex predators in their own right, froze in place, their hands halfway to the lock on the decoy van. Their heads turned in perfect, synchronised unison, a clockwork mechanism breaking down as it processed an impossible input.

Then Rajan stepped into the light. He did not charge. He did not rush. He simply emerged from the darkness of the garage, a flowing mountain of orange and black, and stood at the threshold. Rain began to speckle his magnificent coat, turning the fiery orange to a deep, wet umber. He was bigger than they could have imagined, a creature of myth and nightmare made flesh. His massive head was raised, his golden eyes sweeping over the scene, taking in the black vehicles, the frozen men, the terrified figure of Finn scrambling into the butcher’s van. His gaze was not one of aggression, but of absolute, undisputed sovereignty. This was his territory now, and these strange, small creatures were trespassing. He let out another sound, a low, rumbling chuff that vibrated through the wet tarmac, a sound that said, *I am here. What are you going to do about it?*

That was the moment the men’s professional composure finally shattered. The illusion of control evaporated in the face of five hundred pounds of raw, unpredictable reality. One of the men fumbled inside his coat, his hand emerging not with a firearm, but with a bulky tranquilizer rifle. It was a tool for veterinarians, for zookeepers, for containing a known quantity in a controlled environment. It was a pathetic, laughable response to the monarch who now held court before them. They were prepared for an asset transfer, not a confrontation with a god of the wild. They were paralysed, caught between their objective at the Luton van and the terrifying, immediate problem that stood ten yards away.

This was Moira’s window. This was the chaos she had calculated. While all eyes were locked on the tiger, she ran. It was not a graceful or athletic movement; it was a desperate, lurching scramble across the potholed tarmac, her boots splashing through grimy puddles. She was a drab, grey figure, a mere accountant, moving across a stage dominated by titans. She wrenched open the driver’s side door of the battered refrigerated van, the metal groaning in protest, and threw herself into the driver’s seat. Finn was beside her, his face ashen, his hands gripping the dashboard as if it were the only solid thing in a dissolving world. "Drive," he breathed, the word a prayer. "For the love of all that is holy, Moira, drive."

Her fingers, slick with rain and trembling with adrenaline, fumbled with the keys. The engine turned over once, twice, then caught with a rattling roar of its own, a pathetic mechanical echo of the sound that still dominated the landscape. She slammed the van into gear. As the vehicle lurched forward, she risked a single glance towards the black Range Rover. The tinted rear window was gliding down. In the aperture, she saw her uncle’s face. The mask of calm, patrician control was gone, replaced by a visage of pure, undiluted fury. His mouth was open, shouting a command that was lost in the noise of her engine and the rain. He had been outmanoeuvred, out-thought, his perfect, brutal equation solved by a variable he had dismissed as insignificant. His eyes met hers, and in them she saw no hint of surrender, only the promise of a terrible, boundless retribution.

She wrenched the wheel, and the van careened around the corner of the building, breaking the line of sight. She floored the accelerator. The old butcher’s van shuddered and complained, but it picked up speed, its tyres spraying a wake of dirty water as it sped through the desolate industrial park. In the passenger seat, Finn began to laugh. It was a wild, hysterical sound, teetering on the edge of a sob. "You did it," he gasped, his laughter punctuated by ragged breaths. "You magnificent, terrifying, insane woman. You unleashed a tiger on them. You created a diversion with a Bengal tiger."

Moira’s hands were clamped tight on the steering wheel, her knuckles white. She kept her eyes fixed on the road, on the grey, rain-lashed tarmac that was leading them away from Alistair, away from the cage, away from the life that had been prescribed for her. She had stolen a tiger, started a corporate war, kidnapped her best friend from a kidnapping, and faced down a tyrant, all before noon. The neat columns of her old life were a distant, hazy memory. Her new ledger was a mess of high-stakes gambles and impossible outcomes, and for the first time in her forty-two years, it felt perfectly, gloriously balanced. The butcher’s van rattled onto the main road, merging with the ordinary traffic, a grimy, anonymous vehicle carrying two fugitives and the ghost of a roar. They were free. And they were hunted.The laughter was a fragile thing, a glass sculpture of hysteria and shock that shattered the moment Moira swung the van onto the Great Western Road. It died in Finn’s throat, replaced by a ragged, gasping silence as the reality of their situation began to flood the small, rattling cab. They were just another grubby commercial vehicle in the endless river of midday traffic, a tiny, anonymous secret hiding in plain sight. But the secret they carried was a conflagration, a city-wide emergency they had just ignited. The rumble of the van’s old diesel engine was a poor substitute for the roar that was still echoing in their bones.

“We need to ditch the van,” Moira said, her voice a low, raw rasp. Her knuckles were bone-white on the steering wheel, her gaze fixed on the road ahead with an intensity that seemed to be the only thing holding the world together. She was not looking in the rearview mirror; she knew, with a certainty that went deeper than sight, what was back there. A web of power and fury, with her uncle at its centre, its strands already beginning to stretch across the city to find them. Finn stared at her, his face pale and blotchy, his usual vibrant energy extinguished. The cashmere jumper was ruined, streaked with grime from the floor of Alistair’s makeshift cell, a sad, expensive casualty of their war. “Ditch the van? Moira, we need to ditch the country! We need to find a fishing trawler to Iceland and learn how to knit puffin-themed jumpers for a living! You don’t understand what you’ve done. You’ve poked the dragon, and now it’s going to burn down the entire village to find us.”

“I understand perfectly, Finn,” she said, her tone dangerously calm. The accountant had retaken the helm, her mind a cold, clear space of logistical challenges. The terror and rage were still there, but they had been filed away under ‘non-essential liabilities’. “Phase One: Immediate Disengagement. We need to be untraceable. The van is a liability. It’s registered to a butcher in Partick who my uncle’s people will be interviewing within the hour. We need cash, untraceable clothing, and a different mode of transport. In that order.” She took a sharp left, turning away from the main thoroughfares and plunging into a warren of backstreets in the West End. Every corner they turned felt like a small victory, a temporary severing of a thread.

Finn was shaking his head, his hands scrubbing at his face. “You’re talking about this like it’s a tax audit. Moira, there is a tiger. A literal, actual Bengal tiger, loose in an industrial estate because of us. He’ll be all over the news. The police, animal control… everyone will be looking for him. And for the people who let him out.” The thought hit Moira with the force of a physical blow, a shard of ice in her gut. Rajan. In her frantic, desperate plan to save Finn, to escape her uncle, she had unleashed him. She had opened his cage, but she had released him into a world of tarmac, steel, and men with rifles. She had not freed him. She had simply moved him from her cage to a larger, more dangerous one, a concrete wilderness where he was the ultimate outsider. The guilt was a suffocating weight. What would happen to him? Cornered, terrified, hunted. The very fate she had sworn to protect him from, she had now engineered on a city-wide scale.

She pulled the van into a grimy alley behind a row of charity shops, the engine cutting out with a final, shuddering cough. In the sudden silence, she could hear Finn’s ragged breathing and the frantic drumming of her own heart. She rested her forehead against the steering wheel for a moment, the cold, cheap plastic a small, solid point of reality. “I had no choice, Finn,” she whispered, the words meant more for herself than for him. “It was him or you.” Finn reached out and placed a hand on her shoulder. His touch was hesitant, but his grip was firm. “I know,” he said, his voice soft, the hysteria replaced by a deep, weary empathy. “I know, Moira. But what happens to him now doesn’t change what happens to us. We’re not just fugitives from your uncle. We’re fugitives from the six o’clock news.”

He was right. The problem had expanded exponentially. They needed to move, and they needed a destination. Moira lifted her head, her mind clear again. “My flat,” she said. “We have to go back. It’s the last place they’ll expect us to go now. It’s the centre of the web. The one place they won’t be looking.” Finn stared at her as if she had just proposed they learn to fly. “Have you lost your mind? Your uncle has probably already changed the locks and redecorated in some tasteful shade of revenge! It’s a trap!” “No,” Moira countered, her certainty absolute. “He thinks he’s won the first move. He thinks we are running scared, heading for the hills. He won’t expect a strategic return to the point of origin. I have emergency cash hidden there. My passport. Things we need. We will be in and out in ten minutes. It’s a calculated risk.”

The journey back on foot was a nightmare of paranoia. Every passerby seemed to stare a little too long, every police siren in the distance felt like it was for them. They moved through the familiar streets of her neighbourhood like ghosts, strangers in their own city. The black saloon and the Range Rovers were gone from Hyndland Street. A single, unmarked police car sat at the corner, a quiet, watchful presence, its occupants likely tasked with keeping the media away from what was now a crime scene. They slipped in through the back green, a shared patch of damp grass and overflowing bins, and up the rear staircase, a dark, narrow spiral of stone and peeling paint used for taking out rubbish. The back door to Moira’s flat was a simple wooden one, a flimsy barrier compared to the steel fortress at the front. The lock, thankfully, was untouched. Inside, the flat was cold and silent, a museum of the previous day’s battle. The living room was pristine, the table set for a dinner that had ended in betrayal. A faint scent of her uncle’s cologne still hung in the air, a violation.

While Finn stood guard at the back window, his body a tight coil of anxiety, Moira moved with practiced speed. From a hollowed-out copy of ‘Advanced Taxation Principles’, she retrieved a thick bundle of cash and her passport. From the bottom of her wardrobe, she pulled a worn canvas rucksack and began stuffing it with practical, anonymous clothing – dark jumpers, waterproof trousers, sturdy walking boots. She was erasing the accountant, assembling the uniform of a fugitive. As she worked, she switched on the small television in the corner of her bedroom, keeping the volume on a barely-audible whisper. The local news channel was already running a breaking story. The image on the screen was a helicopter shot of the Anniesland industrial estate, crawling with police cars and white animal control vans. The headline beneath it read: *‘TIGER ON THE LOOSE: GLASGOW IN LOCKDOWN.’*

A stern-faced police superintendent was giving a press conference. “We are responding to a serious incident… believed to be the work of extremist animal rights activists…” Moira felt a bitter laugh escape her. Activist. Her uncle was already spinning the narrative, painting her not as a victim, but as a dangerous fanatic. The report cut to an interview with a witness, a pale, terrified-looking man. It was one of Alistair’s grey suits. “It was a coordinated attack,” he said, his voice professionally grave. “They were dangerous. Unstable. The woman… she seemed to have some kind of bond with the animal. She spoke to it. She called it… Rajan.” The name, spoken on television, broadcast to the entire city, was a branding iron against her skin. She was no longer anonymous. She was the woman who had unleashed the tiger.

“We have to go,” Finn hissed from the doorway, his face stark with fear. “Now, Moira.” She stuffed the last of the clothes into the rucksack, slung it over her shoulder, and took one last look around the flat that had been her prison and her sanctuary. It was over. That part of her life was gone, burned to the ground. They slipped out the back way, melting back into the anonymous grey of the city. At a bus station, surrounded by the unquestioning hustle of ordinary people going about their ordinary lives, they boarded the first coach heading north. As the bus pulled away from the city, leaving the tenements and the cranes and the weight of her uncle’s power behind, Moira looked out of the window at the weeping sky. They were heading into the vast, empty expanse of the Highlands. It was a flight towards emptiness, towards a landscape vast enough to swallow secrets. But she knew, with a chilling certainty, that they were not running towards safety. They were simply choosing a new, wilder battlefield.The bus was a purgatory of condensation and the smell of damp wool. It rattled north, its motion a monotonous, lulling rhythm that did nothing to soothe the frantic, jagged edges of Moira’s thoughts. Outside the rain-streaked window, Glasgow’s familiar sandstone bled into the grey sprawl of suburbia, which in turn dissolved into the bleak, rolling green of the countryside. With every mile, she felt the invisible tether to her old life stretching, thinning, until it finally snapped, leaving her adrift in a terrifying new geography. She was a figure in a column that no longer existed, a number without a ledger.

Finn sat beside her, huddled into himself, a vibrant bird stripped of its plumage. He had been silent for the better part of an hour, staring out of his own window, his reflection a pale, ghostly mask superimposed over the fleeting landscape. The shock had worn off, leaving behind a deep, bone-weary exhaustion and a fear that was quiet but all-pervasive. He had been kidnapped, threatened, and was now a fugitive, his entire life packed into a carrier bag at his feet containing a bottle of water and a hastily purchased, luridly coloured waterproof jacket.

“He called him Captain Winky,” Moira said, her voice a low murmur that was almost lost in the drone of the engine. It was the first thing either of them had said since leaving the city limits.

Finn turned his head slowly, his eyes hollow. “What?”

“The cat,” she clarified. “In the flat. The security question. You remembered his name. Captain Winky.”

A ghost of a smile touched Finn’s lips, a faint tremor. “Of course I did. He was a vicious little monster. Used to attack my ankles. Hated everyone. But he’d sleep on my chest at night, purring like a tiny, defective engine.” He sighed, the memory a brief, painful flicker of a world that no longer existed. “It feels like a hundred years ago, Moira. A different lifetime.” He looked at her then, his gaze sharp with a question he seemed afraid to ask. “Where are we going? You said north. The Highlands is a very large, very wet place to hide. We can’t just wander into the heather and hope for the best.”

Moira pulled the worn canvas rucksack onto her lap. From an inside pocket, she retrieved a small, folded piece of paper. It was an old ordnance survey map, creased and softened with age, its lines faded. She unfolded it, revealing a section of the Cairngorms, a wild, remote knot of mountains and lochs. She pointed to a tiny, almost invisible symbol beside a sliver of blue marked ‘Loch Avon’.

“There,” she said. “It’s a bothy. Faindouran Lodge. It was owned by my grandmother’s family, centuries ago. It’s nothing now but stone walls and a roof, maintained by the mountain association. It’s isolated. Miles from any road. No electricity, no running water, no phone signal. It’s a ghost on a map. It’s a place you only go if you’re deliberately trying to disappear.”

Finn stared at the map, at the dense, intimidating contour lines that swirled around the tiny black square of the bothy. “A stone hut. In the middle of nowhere. In November. Moira, darling, this isn’t a plan for survival; it’s a beautifully illustrated suicide note. We’ll freeze to death or be eaten by midges. Assuming we don’t get lost and die of exposure first.”

“The midges are gone by now,” Moira said, her tone clinical, factual. “And I have cash. We’ll get off the bus in Aviemore. We can buy supplies. Tinned food, sleeping bags, a gas stove. Everything we need to last a few weeks. It’s the last place he’ll look. Alistair’s world is one of five-star hotels and private jets. He doesn’t do… damp. Or inconvenience. He will assume we’ve gone to an airport, a ferry terminal. He won’t be looking for us in a place that has fallen off his balance sheet.”

The bus pulled into the small, bustling town of Aviemore under a sky that had deepened to the colour of a bruise. The air that hit them as they stepped off the coach was sharp and cold, laced with the clean, resinous scent of pine and the damp smell of earth. It was the antithesis of the city’s exhaust fumes and anxiety. For a moment, it felt like freedom. But the feeling was fleeting. The town was filled with hardy, cheerful people in brightly coloured waterproofs, hikers and climbers preparing for or recovering from their tussles with the mountains. Moira and Finn, in their city clothes and their haunted expressions, felt as conspicuous as spies.

They moved through the outdoor supply shop with the grim efficiency of soldiers provisioning for a siege. Moira was methodical, her choices ruthlessly practical. High-energy food, thermal layers, water purification tablets, a first-aid kit. Finn, trailing in her wake, seemed lost, picking up and putting down brightly coloured carabiners and GPS units like a bewildered magpie. He was a creature of sequins and spotlights, of wit and warmth, and he was being dragged into a world of Gore-Tex and survival rations. The chasm between his life and this new, brutal reality had never felt wider.

As Moira paid in cash, her eyes were drawn to a small television screen behind the counter, tuned to a 24-hour news channel. The volume was off, but the images were sickeningly familiar. A helicopter shot of a bewildered-looking deer carcass in a suburban garden. A grainy mobile phone video of a large, striped shape moving through the dawn mist in a public park. And then, a live shot of a grim-faced woman in a police uniform, a map of Glasgow behind her, its western sector shaded in a menacing red. A moving ticker at the bottom of the screen read: *‘Search for escaped tiger enters its eighth hour. Public warned to remain indoors. Authorities confirm animal is “extremely dangerous and unpredictable”.’* Moira felt the food she’d just eaten turn to acid in her stomach. Unpredictable. Dangerous. They were talking about him like he was a rabid dog, a mindless monster. They didn’t see the intelligence, the quiet dignity, the terrible, logical beauty. They just saw a threat to be neutralized.

Their final purchase was a taxi, paid for with a ruinous amount of cash, to take them as far as the road would allow, to the car park at the edge of the Glenmore Forest Park. The driver, a talkative local with a thick Highland accent, kept the radio on, his cheerful commentary on the landscape punctuated by grim updates from the city they had just fled. “Absolute madness, eh?” he said, shaking his head. “A tiger. In Glasgow. Some folk are sayin’ it’s these animal liberation headbangers. Serves ’em right if it eats one of them, I say.” Finn flinched in the back seat, but Moira remained impassive, her face a mask of stone, her gaze fixed on the darkening mountains that loomed ahead.

The road ended at a deserted car park. The sky was spitting a cold, persistent drizzle. The taxi drove away, its red tail-lights vanishing into the gloom, leaving them utterly alone. The silence that descended was absolute, broken only by the whisper of wind in the pine trees and the distant cry of a bird. Before them, a rough track snaked away into a vast, empty landscape of bruised heather, dark peat, and ancient, slumbering mountains. It was beautiful, and it was terrifying.

"Well," Finn said, pulling the collar of his new, brutally unflattering waterproof jacket up to his ears. "Here we are. The edge of the world." He looked at Moira, his face pale in the fading light. "Are you sure about this, Moira? Once we walk down that path, there’s no coming back."

Moira shouldered her heavy rucksack, the weight of it both a burden and a comfort. She looked into the vast, unforgiving wilderness that was to be their sanctuary. It was a place without ledgers, without spreadsheets, a place where the only bottom line was survival. "I've never been more sure of anything in my life," she said. "Come on. We've got a long walk before dark."

The rumble began in the floorboards, a resonance so deep it felt less like a sound and more like a tectonic shifting of the world. Moira MacLeod, bathed in the aqueous grey light of a Glasgow morning, held her breath and listened. It was not the shudder of a passing lorry on Great Western Road, nor the subterranean groan of the underground. This was a living sound, a bass note of pure, carnivorous life that had no place among the tenements and the perpetually damp pavements. It was the sound of Rajan, and it meant he was waking.

In her past life, the one that had ended precisely six weeks and three days ago, Moira’s mornings had been scored by the polite chime of a digital alarm and the burble of a kettle. She was, by trade and by temperament, an accountant. Her world was one of double-entry bookkeeping, of balancing ledgers and navigating the labyrinthine corridors of HMRC tax codes. It was a world of straight lines, of quantifiable truths, where every debit had its credit and the bottom line was the ultimate arbiter of reality. There was a quiet satisfaction in it, the same kind one might get from arranging pebbles by size. But it was a grey satisfaction, a muted pleasure. Her life had been a long, neat column of figures that balanced perfectly but added up to very little.

Now, her world was this. The low, gut-deep thrum of a five-hundred-pound Bengal tiger stirring in what was once her spare bedroom.

She padded barefoot from her small kitchen, the linoleum cool against her skin, a mug of steaming tea clutched in her hands. The door to the spare room was reinforced with a steel frame she’d had custom-built by a bewildered welder from Maryhill, a man who’d assumed it was for a paranoid art collection and charged her accordingly. A heavy-duty bolt, the kind you’d see on a bank vault, was slid home. Through the judas hole, a new addition drilled at eye level, she could see him. Rajan. A blaze of orange and black in the gloom, a living fire. He was stretched out on the floor, his massive head resting on his paws. One colossal shoulder twitched, and the rumble intensified, a soft exhalation of air that smelled faintly of old meat and something wild, something ancient.

He was beautiful. A terrible, logical beauty. Every stripe was a perfect stroke of black against the fiery canvas of his coat. His power was not chaotic; it was contained, efficient, a masterpiece of evolutionary engineering. The accountant in her appreciated the sheer, brutal economy of his design. No wasted movement. No superfluous detail. He was the apex, the final, terrifying entry in nature’s ledger.

The first complaint had come from Mr. Henderson in 2B. A note, slipped under her door, written in a cramped, indignant script. *Madam*, it began, with a level of formality that promised war, *I am not one to pry, but the odours emanating from your flat have become a matter of some concern. It is a pungent, almost feral smell. Furthermore, my prize-winning petunias on the balcony appear to have been… unnerved. Several have wilted.* Moira had almost laughed. Unnerved petunias. She’d imagined them trembling in their little ceramic pots, their pink and white faces pale with fear at the scent of a predator three doors down.

The second complaint had not been a note. It had been Mr. Henderson himself, his face a blotchy pink, standing a safe three feet from her door when she’d opened it. "It's the noises now," he'd hissed, spittle flying from his lips. "A growling. A low, guttural… I don't know what you're keeping in there, lass, but this is a respectable building."

Moira had given him the thinnest of smiles. "It's a new boiler, Mr. Henderson. A continental model. Very powerful."

He hadn't believed her. The suspicion in his watery eyes was as plain as the Clyde. He was the first fissure in the fragile, impossible world she had built. She knew he wouldn’t be the last.

Her mobile buzzed on the counter, a frantic, angry vibration. The screen lit up with a picture of a man in a feather boa and glitter eyeshadow. Finn. Of course. She let it ring for a moment, gathering herself, then answered.

"Moira, darling, have you lost your ever-loving, tartan-trimmed mind?" The voice was a theatrical boom, even through the tiny speaker. "I've just had Brenda from the corner shop on the phone. She says wee Henderson is telling everyone you're harbouring a wild animal. She asked me if it was a caiman. A caiman! In Partick! I told her you were far too sensible for reptiles, that you were probably just on a new, very aggressive protein diet. For God's sake, Moira, talk to me. Tell me you haven't done what I think you've done."

Moira leaned her forehead against the cool plaster of the wall. "Hello, Finn. It's not a caiman."

"Oh, thank Christ for that," he sighed, a rush of static. "For a minute there I had visions of you wrestling something scaly in the bathtub. So, what is it? A very large dog? One of those wolf-hybrids that look like they've escaped from a Tolkien novel?"

She took a sip of her tea. The warmth did little to calm the tremor in her hand. "He's a tiger, Finn."

Silence. For a full ten seconds, the only sound was the hum of the refrigerator and the distant, constant sigh of Glasgow traffic. Moira could picture Finn perfectly: standing in his chaotic, sequin-strewn flat, one hand on his hip, his mouth agape.

"A… what?" he finally whispered, the boom completely gone, replaced by a note of pure, unadulterated shock. "Moira, please tell me you're joking. Please tell me this is one of your strange, dry, accountant jokes that nobody ever gets."

"Rajan," she said, the name feeling solid and real on her tongue. "His name is Rajan. The private zoo in the Borders went bankrupt. They were going to put him down. It was all legal, Finn. The transfer of ownership, the permits for a Class D dangerous animal. It's all filed. In triplicate."

"Filed? In triplicate?" Finn’s voice was climbing the octave scale, approaching a shriek. "You filed paperwork to adopt a sodding tiger? We're not talking about a hamster, Moira! You can't just keep it in a cage with some sawdust and a wee wheel! This isn't a spreadsheet you can just delete if it doesn't balance! This is a… a stripey, people-eating apocalypse machine!"

"He's very calm," Moira said, though her heart was hammering against her ribs. "He just sleeps mostly."

"He sleeps now! What happens when he wakes up and decides his new favourite chew toy is your landlord? Or Mr. Henderson’s 'unnerved' petunias? Or Mr. Henderson himself!"

Moira closed her eyes, the image of Rajan's sleeping face in her mind. The soft velvet of his nose. The sheer bulk of him. People thought she was mad. Finn thought she was mad. Mr. Henderson definitely thought she was mad. And perhaps she was. Perhaps, after forty-two years of sensible shoes and tax returns, of a life so quiet it was barely audible, a person was entitled to one, glorious, spectacular act of madness. She hadn’t planned it. She'd seen the advertisement online, a desperate plea from a failing sanctuary. She'd seen his picture – not a majestic beast in the wild, but a defeated animal in a concrete pen, his amber eyes holding a profound emptiness she recognised in her own mirror. And in that moment, something within her, some long-dormant, reckless impulse, had taken over. The subsequent weeks had been a blur of paperwork, of draining her savings, of lying to welders and delivery men.

It was a rebellion. A rebellion against the grey. A rebellion against a life that had begun to feel like a long, slow subtraction. Rajan wasn't an addition; he was a multiplication, an exponential explosion of life and danger and consequence in the centre of her ordered world. He was an anchor, mooring her to a reality that was visceral and terrifying and, for the first time, truly her own.

"I have to go, Finn," she said softly. "It's time for his breakfast."

"Breakfast? What are you feeding him? Postmen?"

"Half a dozen chickens. The butcher delivers. He thinks I'm running a very niche catering company."

She hung up before Finn could muster another argument, his frantic squawking cut short. The flat was silent again, save for the low rumble from the spare room. It was louder now, expectant. Moira went to the industrial freezer she’d installed in the hall, its constant hum the new baseline of her home. She pulled open the heavy lid. Inside, frozen poultry lay stacked like white bricks. She hauled out a bundle, the plastic crinkling, the frozen weight of them solid and real in her hands.

As she unbolted the spare room door, her hand hesitated for a fraction of a second. Every single time, there was that flicker of primal fear, the jolt to her nervous system that screamed *wrong, wrong, wrong*. An accountant from Glasgow does not open a door to a tiger. But she did. She slid the bolt, turned the handle, and pushed the reinforced door inward.

The air that hit her was thick with his presence, a warm, musky wave that filled her lungs. Rajan was on his feet now, his tail twitching, a low, chuffing sound vibrating in his chest. His amber eyes, flecked with gold, fixed on her. They held no malice, only a vast, unnerving intelligence. He was not a pet. He was a power she was permitted, for now, to coexist with. The world had shrunk to the size of this flat. And it was glorious. She tossed the chickens onto the rubber-matted floor. He lowered his great head, the muscles in his shoulders rippling under his striped skin, and began to eat. As she backed out and secured the door, she saw a crisp, brown envelope on the doormat, half-slid under the door. It hadn't been there when she'd woken up. With a growing sense of dread, she bent to pick it up. It was thick, formal paper. The logo of the Glasgow City Council was embossed in the top corner.

Her fingers, which could fly over a calculator with unerring accuracy, felt clumsy and thick as she broke the seal. The paper within was crisp and heavy, the kind of expensive stock used for demands and final notices. For a moment, the old Moira, the accountant, surfaced and noted the profligate waste of taxpayer money on stationery. Then she read the first line, and the accountant drowned in a fresh wave of adrenaline. It was from the Environmental Health department, a follow-up to her application under the Dangerous Wild Animals Act. The official, bureaucratic language was a world away from Mr. Henderson’s spidery script, but the message was infinitely more threatening.

*…pursuant to your declaration… a mandatory inspection of the premises is required to ensure the enclosure meets the stringent safety and welfare standards as outlined in the Act. An officer will call upon your property, 3A, 47 Hyndland Street, on Friday 17th November at 10:00 AM to conduct this assessment.* Friday. That was two days from now. The words swam before her eyes. *Stringent safety and welfare standards.* She thought of her spare room, the reinforced door and the rubber matting. It had felt so secure, so impossibly daring. Now, under the cold lens of bureaucracy, it felt like a child’s pathetic fort. The law, which she had so carefully followed, which she had thought was her shield, was turning out to be the very weapon that would undo her.

A loud crack of bone echoed from the spare room, followed by the wet, rhythmic sound of tearing flesh. Rajan, oblivious, was enjoying his breakfast. The sound, which minutes ago had been a secret thrill, now felt like a ticking clock counting down to her ruin. The sheer, beautiful, terrible reality of him was contained in that room, and in two days, a man with a clipboard and a checklist would stand on this very spot. A man who would not see a rebellion against the grey, or a creature of terrible beauty. He would see a violation, a five-hundred-pound problem that needed to be removed, a column of figures that didn’t just fail to balance, but threatened to bring the entire ledger crashing down.

Panic, cold and sharp, lanced through her. She could call them, feign illness, buy a few more days. But the problem would remain. The inspection was inevitable. They would come, and they would see, and they would take him. The thought was unbearable. They would take him back to a cage, or worse. That emptiness she had seen in his eyes in the sanctuary photo would return, and this time she would be its cause. She would be the one who had offered him a fleeting, impossible home only to snatch it away. The quiet satisfaction of her old life had been a muted pleasure, but this new life, this terrifying, vibrant, impossible life, was everything. She would not let it be audited out of existence.

Leaning her back against the hall wall, she slid down until she was sitting on the floor, the official letter a flimsy, damning piece of evidence in her lap. The accountant’s mind, the part of her that saw patterns and pathways, that could navigate the most tortuous of legal mazes, began to stir. It was no longer a question of balancing a budget; it was a problem of logistics. The problem was not the tiger. The problem was the flat. The problem was the inspector. For forty-eight hours, she had to make a tiger, a living, breathing, five-hundred-pound Bengal tiger, disappear from a third-floor flat in the middle of Glasgow. The idea was preposterous, a fantasy. But then, so was everything else she had done for the last six weeks. A slow, determined smile touched Moira’s lips. It wasn't a spreadsheet, as Finn had said. It was far more interesting. It was a creative accounting challenge on a scale she had never imagined.

The smile was a strange, alien thing on her usually composed face. It was sharp and calculating, the expression of a predator that has just spotted a weakness in its prey's defenses. The prey, in this case, was the monolithic institution of the Glasgow City Council. The weakness was its faith in procedure, in forms and checklists. Bureaucracy, she knew from long and bitter experience, could be a weapon, but it could also be a blindfold. An inspector would come looking for specific things, ticking specific boxes. They would be looking for a non-compliant enclosure for a dangerous animal. If she could just, for the span of an hour, ensure there was no animal and no non-compliant enclosure to be found, then the boxes could not be ticked. The problem wasn’t the tiger; it was his context.

She rose from the floor with a fluid motion that surprised her. The adrenaline was a clean, cold fire in her veins. She left the council letter on the hall table, a declaration of war, and went to her laptop. The faint hum of Rajan’s digestion from the spare room was no longer a sound of impending doom, but the engine of her own resolve. She sat at the small desk in the alcove of her living room, the same desk where she had once wrestled with the tax affairs of dentists and pub landlords, and began her campaign. The search terms were simple: *‘Dangerous Wild Animals Act 1976, Schedule of Conditions’, ‘Glasgow City Council, DWA, Inspection Guidelines’.*

The results were a deluge of legalese and dry, bureaucratic prose that would have made the old Moira’s heart sing. She devoured them. *Double-door entry system with interlocking mechanism. Impervious, washable surfaces on all walls and floors. Dedicated drainage connected directly to the sewer main, incorporating a solids trap. Minimum enclosure size of 30 square metres, plus an additional 15 square metres for an external, secured exercise area.* She scrolled through page after page of requirements, each one a nail in her coffin. Her spare room, with its single reinforced door and rubber mats, was a laughable travesty. She hadn’t been audacious; she’d been naive. But the knowledge didn't bring despair. It brought clarity. She wasn't just hiding Rajan. She had to dismantle and hide the entire concept of him ever having been there.

Her fingers flew across the keyboard, creating a new file. Not a spreadsheet, but a project plan. It had headings: *Phase 1: Decontamination and Obfuscation. Phase 2: Asset Relocation. Phase 3: The Audit. Phase 4: Reinstatement.* Under each heading, she began to create a list of tasks. *Remove freezer. Steam-clean carpets. De-Rajanify spare room. Source industrial-grade ozone generator. Patch judas hole.* The list grew longer, more detailed, more impossible. And at the heart of it, the gaping, terrifying hole of Phase 2: Asset Relocation. She couldn’t do it alone. There was only one person she could call. She picked up her mobile and dialled.

Finn answered on the first ring, his voice tight with anxiety. "Don't tell me. He's eaten the postman and you need me to help you dispose of the mailbag."

"I have a logistical problem, Finn," Moira said, her tone all business. She was the accountant again, presenting a challenge to a colleague.

"A logistical problem? Darling, you have a Bengal tiger in your guest room. You're a walking, talking, Glaswegian logistical problem. What now?"

"I have an inspection. Environmental Health. Friday morning. Ten o'clock." She let the words hang in the air.

The silence on the other end was profound. She could hear the faint clink of what was probably Finn’s third gin of the morning. "An inspection," he said finally, his voice flat. "As in, an official person is coming to your flat to inspect the… the stripey apocalypse machine."

"Precisely. And according to their guidelines, my flat is approximately one hundred percent non-compliant. Which means they will take him."

"Well, yes! That's what normal people would call 'the authorities solving the problem of their friend keeping a man-eater next to the airing cupboard'!"

"He is not a man-eater," Moira snapped, with more heat than she intended. "And they will not be taking him. That is the logistical issue I need your help with. He needs to not be here during the inspection."

Another pause. "Moira," Finn said, his voice dangerously calm. "Where, in the name of all that is holy and deep-fried, do you propose to 'relocate' a five-hundred-pound predator? Are you going to ask him to pop down to the Kelvingrove for an hour to look at the art? Maybe he can hide out in my spare room? He'd have a fabulous time with my boa collection, I'm sure, right up until he ate them and then me."

"I have a plan," Moira said, looking at the skeletal project file on her screen. "It's still in the early stages, but it's feasible. I need a van, Finn. A big one. A Luton van, with a tail lift. And I need you to hire it."

Finn made a noise that was half-choke, half-laugh. "A van? You're going to move him like a wardrobe? Moira, he's a sentient being with claws the size of steak knives! You can't just put him in a van! What are you going to do, write 'FRAGILE' on the side?"

"We'll need a crate, obviously. And a sedative," Moira mused, already thinking ahead. Then she stopped herself. The thought of drugging Rajan, of seeing him limp and helpless, made her stomach clench. It was too risky, too much of a violation. "No. No sedative. It's too dangerous for him."

"NO SEDATIVE?" Finn’s shriek was so high-pitched it made the phone speaker distort. "ARE YOU INSANE? YOU WANT TO PUT AN AWAKE, FULLY-FUNCTIONAL TIGER INTO A RENTED VAN IN THE MIDDLE OF PARTICK? I CAN SEE THE HEADLINES NOW: 'LOCAL DRAG QUEEN DEVOURED IN DIY HOUSE-MOVE HORROR'!"

"It's a third-floor flat, Finn. That's the primary obstacle. Getting him down the stairs," Moira continued, her mind already working through the geometry of the tenement stairwell, the turn on the landing, the width of the main door. "But I have an idea for that too. I need rope. A lot of it. And a block and tackle. And several of those heavy-duty removal blankets."

There was a long-suffering sigh from the other end of the line. It was the sound of a man surrendering to the magnificent, terrifying madness of his best friend. "Block and tackle. A van. No sedative. Moira, this isn't a plan. This is a suicide note with a to-do list attached." He paused. "I'll be there in an hour. And I'm bringing valium. For me, not the tiger."

True to his word, Finn arrived in fifty-eight minutes. He didn’t knock. He had his own key, and let himself in with the quiet care of a seasoned burglar, a stark contrast to his usual grand entrance. He was a vision of controlled panic, dressed in black skinny jeans, a deceptively simple cashmere jumper, and a silk scarf patterned with what looked like agitated parakeets. The only signs of his inner turmoil were the faint tremor in the hand that held his car keys and the fact that he was wearing two different, albeit equally expensive, designer boots. He found Moira on the living room floor, surrounded by rolls of wallpaper samples, paint charts, and a frighteningly detailed, hand-drawn diagram of the tenement stairwell.

"Right," Finn said, his voice a low, dramatic whisper as he closed the door behind him. "The patient is prepped, the operating theatre is ready. Just tell me, Doctor Frankenstein, where do we hide the monster?" He gestured vaguely towards the spare room door, from which a contented, digestive silence now emanated. Moira didn’t look up from her drawing, where she was using a protractor to measure the angle of the turn on the first-floor landing. "He is not a monster, Finn. And we are not hiding him. We are temporarily relocating a valuable and sensitive asset. It’s a logistical exercise." Finn stared at her. The accountant was fully in command, her face set in a mask of intense concentration. The soft, hesitant woman who used to worry about misplacing a receipt was gone, replaced by a cool-headed general planning a deeply illegal military operation.

"An 'asset'?" Finn walked over and peered at the diagram. It was annotated with Moira's neat, precise script, full of figures for tensile strength and load distribution. "You've done stress calculations. On the banisters. Moira, you've done a structural survey for the express purpose of smuggling a tiger." Moira finally looked up, pushing a stray strand of mousy brown hair from her forehead. "Of course. I wouldn't proceed without the data. The main joists under the landing are solid oak. They’ll hold. The problem is the turning radius. We’ll have to cant the crate at a thirty-seven-degree angle to clear the newel post. It will be tight."

"The crate," Finn repeated, his voice hollow. "Please don't tell me you've also got a tiger-sized crate stored under your bed." Moira almost smiled. "It's in a lock-up in Anniesland. I had it commissioned at the same time as the door. I told the fabricator it was for a particularly fragile piece of modern sculpture. He believed me. People will believe anything if you say it’s for art." She stood up, her joints cracking in protest. "Phase One is Decontamination. We start with the freezer. It has to go. Then we steam clean everything. Any lingering scent, any trace of dander, has to be eradicated. The inspector will have a sensitive nose, but I'm betting it's not as sensitive as a sniffer dog's. We're gambling on human fallibility."

The industrial freezer was a monolithic slab of white metal humming innocuously in the hallway. It weighed nearly as much as a small car and was filled with the frozen carcasses of Moira's 'niche catering' business. Together, they unplugged it, the sudden silence in the hall feeling loud and profound. Manoeuvring it was a nightmare of grunted commands and suppressed curses. It was a dead, awkward weight, entirely resistant to their efforts to pivot it around the corner toward the front door. At one point, Finn’s end slipped from his grasp, and the freezer corner hit the floor with a deafening bang that seemed to shake the whole building. They both froze, eyes wide with terror, listening. From the flat below, a faint, familiar cough. Mr. Henderson. They could hear the creak of his floorboards as he moved about, perhaps checking his petunias for signs of fresh unnerving. After a full minute of suffocating silence, the creaking stopped. They waited another two minutes for good measure, breathing in shallow, synchronised pants, before carefully, painstakingly, resuming their task.

By mid-afternoon, they had wrestled the freezer out onto the landing, a monument to their struggle. They were both sweating, dishevelled, and covered in a fine layer of dust. Finn leaned against the wall, chest heaving. "You know," he panted, "for a woman whose primary form of exercise for the last twenty years has been pressing the numbers on a calculator, you're terrifyingly strong." Moira was already moving on, fetching a bucket and a bottle of industrial-strength cleaner from under the sink. "It's adrenaline," she said briskly. "And a clear objective. Now, the spare room. We can't do the floor, but we can do the walls. And the door." She stared at the reinforced steel door, her expression unreadable. The judas hole stared back like a single, dead eye. That had to go. It was a peephole into madness, and the inspector must not be allowed to look through it. She began mixing the cleaner, the sharp, chemical smell of ammonia a brutal assault on the wild, musky air of the flat. It was the scent of erasure, the perfume of her impossible lie.

The door swung open not with a creak, but with the hushed, heavy sweep of well-oiled steel. The room beyond was Rajan’s territory. The air, thick with his warm, animal scent, was a physical presence. He lay on the rubber mats, a mountain of striped muscle, observing them with an unnerving placidity. His breakfast was gone, save for a few stray feathers and a splinter of bone, and he was now engaged in a meticulous post-meal toilette, his tongue, rough as industrial sandpaper, rasping over a colossal forepaw. He lifted his head as they entered, his amber eyes blinking slowly, taking in Finn’s rigid posture and Moira’s determined expression. He seemed less like a prisoner and more like a monarch, mildly curious about the frantic activity of his courtiers. The accountant in Moira had designated the rubber floor mats as a depreciating asset; the rest of the room was a write-off. Claw marks, deep as chisel gouges, scored the plaster by the window, a testament to a brief moment of feline boredom. They were too deep to fill, too flagrant to ignore.

"Right," Finn breathed, pulling the parakeet scarf over his nose and mouth. "Where do we start? With an exorcism?" Moira ignored him, her gaze fixed on the door. It was the most damning piece of evidence. "We can't remove it. But we can make it disappear." She picked up one of the rolls of wallpaper she’d been studying. It was a bold, slightly dizzying art deco pattern of gold fans on a navy background. "You have an eye for this, Finn. Would this be too much for a feature wall?" Finn lowered his scarf, his expression shifting from terror to professional critique. "For a hallway in Partick? Darling, it’s catastrophically over-the-top. It’s perfect." Moira's plan was simple and ludicrous. They would hide the door in plain sight. They would cover the entire hall wall, door included, with the flamboyant paper. The bolt, the handle, the hinges—all would be entombed beneath a layer of paste and print. The judas hole was filled with quick-drying plaster, sanded down with a fury that left Moira's fingers raw, becoming a small, insignificant blemish on the wall, soon to be lost among the golden fans.

What followed was a blur of frantic, whispered labour. Finn, drawing on years of dressing sets for amateur dramatics, became the maestro of the impossible wallpapering job, his earlier panic sublimated into intense creative focus. He matched seams, smoothed bubbles, and cut around the doorframe with a surgeon’s precision, transforming the solid steel barrier into a flat, patterned illusion. While he worked, Moira deployed the steam cleaner, a shrieking, hissing demon of a machine. She attacked every surface, every skirting board, every inch of carpet in the living room and her own bedroom, chasing the ghost of Rajan’s scent with scalding vapour and the sharp tang of ammonia. They moved in a strange, silent tandem, a high-stakes, domestic ballet, fuelled by mugs of stewed tea and the shared, unspoken terror of the ticking clock. By nightfall, the flat was unrecognisable. The hallway was a dark, glamorous tunnel. The air was sterile, chemical. The freezer stood sentinel on the landing, shrouded in a tartan travel rug like a peculiar piece of conceptual art.

The trip to the Anniesland lock-up was a grim, rain-lashed affair. The van Finn had hired felt enormous, a hollow, booming accomplice to their crime. Inside the cold, concrete garage, under a single flickering fluorescent bulb, sat the crate. It was a masterpiece of paranoia, a welded aluminium box with reinforced bars, solid rubber wheels, and a locking mechanism that looked like it had been salvaged from a submarine. It was large enough to hold a small car. Seeing it, solid and real, Finn’s carefully constructed composure finally cracked. "My God, Moira. You really did think of everything." He ran a hand over the cold metal. "This isn't a logistical problem. This is a life choice. This is the moment you decided that a balanced ledger just wasn't enough." Moira nodded, her hand finding the heavy key in her pocket. The key felt like the only real thing in the world. "I did the maths, Finn. My life was a long, neat column of figures that balanced perfectly but added up to zero. This…" She gestured vaguely towards the crate, the van, the whole impossible situation. "This doesn't balance at all. It's messy, and terrifying, and it's the only thing that's ever felt like a net profit."

Getting the crate up three flights of stairs was a fresh circle of hell that made the freezer feel like a practice run. It was a brutal, scraping, metallic battle against gravity and geometry. They finally wrestled it into the flat just after midnight, its metal frame leaving long, silver scars on the newly wallpapered hallway. Finn collapsed onto the sofa, utterly spent. "Okay," he wheezed, his face pale. "The stage is set. The props are in place. But you've skipped the most important part of the rehearsal, darling. How in the sweet name of Jesus do we get the leading man into the bloody box?" Moira walked to the spare room door and listened. A low, soft rumble came from within, the sound of a vast engine at idle. "I have been preparing him," she said quietly. "For the past two weeks. The crate, the small one I had in the room, has been where he gets his meals. He walks in, I give him his chicken, he walks out. It’s a transaction. He understands transactions." Finn sat bolt upright. "You've been training a tiger with positive reinforcement? Like a bloody dolphin?" "He is not a dolphin, Finn," Moira said, her voice sharp. "He is intelligent. He understands consistency. I am just changing the terms of the transaction. Tomorrow, the transaction will take place in the larger crate. And it will involve a short journey." Her calm, rational tone was more chilling than any scream. She truly believed it would work. Finn stared at her, a new kind of awe dawning in his eyes. She wasn't mad. Or, if she was, her madness had a terrifying internal logic that was almost beautiful.

On the eve of the inspection, an exhausted peace settled over the flat. The faint smell of paint and wallpaper paste overlaid the ghost of ammonia. In the hall, the block and tackle lay coiled like a steel snake, its ropes and pulleys a promise of the morning’s insanity. Moira stood at the living room window, looking down at the empty, rain-slicked street. The Luton van was parked across the road, a huge, anonymous white box waiting to become an accomplice. Behind her, Finn sat nursing a large, neat whisky he’d produced from his bag. "You know what this is, don't you?" he said into the quiet. "It’s your rebellion." Moira didn’t turn. "I was an accountant, Finn. I spent my life making sure things fit into the right columns. Assets, liabilities. Profit, loss. Everything had its place. It was tidy. It was safe. And it was grey. The colour of this sky, the colour of the pavement, the colour of my soul." She finally turned to face him, her expression stripped of its usual guardedness. "Rajan isn't an asset. He’s the thing that doesn't fit in any column. He's a rounding error that blows up the whole system. He’s the opposite of grey." She looked towards the spare room, towards the hidden, papered-over door. "And I will not, I will not, let some man with a clipboard put him back in a box and make my world grey again."

The morning of the inspection dawned not with a bang, but with the familiar, weeping grey of a Glasgow sky. The light that filtered through the living room window was thin and diluted, stripping the colour from everything it touched. It was the colour Moira was fighting against. She and Finn sat in silence, two conspirators in the quiet of a flat that held its breath. The air, scrubbed clean of its wild occupant, smelled only of chemicals and dread. On the floor, the block and tackle lay ready. Every hour of the last thirty-six had been a step in a complex, terrifying equation, and this was the final, brutal calculation. At 6:00 AM precisely, Moira stood up. It was time.

Finn, who had been staring into the dregs of a cold cup of tea, looked up at her, his face a mask of exhaustion and fear. "Is this the part where you play a magical flute and the stripey apocalypse machine follows you meekly into the box?" he asked, his voice a ragged whisper. "Because I really hope you've been taking flute lessons." Moira offered no reply. She walked to the hallway, her bare feet making no sound on the floorboards. She ran her hand over the garish, beautiful wallpaper, feeling for the almost invisible seams. With the tip of a craft knife, she sliced through the paper along the door's edge with a precision that was terrifying to behold. The paper peeled back with a soft, tearing sound, revealing the cold, grey steel beneath. The handle. The bolt. The door to Rajan’s world.

She slid the bolt back, the sound unnaturally loud in the silence. The heavy door swung inward. Rajan was awake, standing in the centre of the room, his tail giving a single, slow lash. He knew. Of course he knew. The absence of the freezer’s hum, the strange chemical smells, the tension that radiated from her like heat—he had processed it all. His amber eyes were not fixed on her, but on the colossal aluminium crate that now took up half the hall, its open door an empty, metallic maw. A low rumble started in his chest, a note of deep uncertainty. For the first time, Moira felt a flicker of doubt. Her plan, so perfect on paper, relied on the cooperation of a five-hundred-pound predator who operated on logic entirely his own.

She did not speak. She simply went to the small fridge in the kitchen and removed the largest of the butcher's chickens. It was her offering, her side of the bargain. She walked slowly back to the threshold of the spare room, her heart a frantic drum against her ribs. She held the chicken out. Rajan looked from the bird to the crate, then back to her face. His intelligence was a palpable force in the room, a silent, complex negotiation taking place in the space between them. He took a step forward, his paws silent on the rubber matting. He was close enough now that she could smell his warm, meaty breath, see the individual whiskers twitching as he scented the air. He nudged the chicken with his nose, but didn't take it. His gaze was locked on the crate.

"He's not going for it," Finn hissed from the safety of the living room archway. "He knows it's a trap. We're going to die here, aren't we? In a wallpapered hallway in Partick." But Moira held her ground, her arm steady, her breathing even. This was the crux of it all, the ultimate test of the fragile, insane trust she had built. *It's just a different box, Rajan,* she thought, pouring all her will into the silent command. *The transaction is the same.* He rumbled again, a deeper, more questioning sound this time. Then, with a fluid grace that defied his size, he turned from her and walked out of the spare room. He padded silently down the hallway, his powerful shoulders brushing against the wall, and without hesitation, stepped into the crate. He turned, his vast body filling the space, and sat, looking out at her. He had understood.

The relief that washed over Moira was so immense it almost buckled her knees. Finn let out a long, shuddering breath he seemed to have been holding for a week. Moira moved quickly, before the moment could break. She tossed the chicken into the crate, and as Rajan lowered his great head to it, she swung the heavy aluminium door shut. The locking mechanism was a series of three thick steel bars that slid into place with heavy, satisfying thuds. The final click of the lock echoed in the hall like a gunshot. He was in. Phase Two was active. The silence that followed was broken by the sickening crack of a chicken bone from within the crate.

The true madness began then. Attaching the block and tackle to the crate and the reinforced ceiling beam Moira had identified in her structural survey was the easy part. The terrifying part was taking the strain. With Finn anchoring the rope and Moira guiding the crate's descent, they began to lower their impossible cargo. The crate, weighing well over half a ton with its occupant, groaned in protest. The ropes creaked, every fibre stretched to its limit. They eased it out of the flat and into the stairwell, a huge, metal box suspended in the echoing space of the tenement close. The turn on the landing, the one Moira had measured with her protractor, was even tighter than her calculations had suggested. The corner of the crate scraped against the wall, gouging a long, deep scar in the plaster and sending a shower of dust and paint flakes down to the floor below. Inside the crate, Rajan let out a low, guttural growl of displeasure at the sudden jolt. They both froze, their blood running cold.

It was then that they heard it. The tell-tale rattle of a lock and the squeak of a door opening on the floor below. 2B. Mr. Henderson. Finn’s face went white. They were trapped, holding a tiger in a box suspended over the main stairwell, while Moira's chief antagonist was directly underneath them. The sound of Mr. Henderson shuffling out to the landing to collect his morning pint of milk was the loudest sound in the universe. "What in God's name is that mess?" he muttered to himself, his voice drifting up the stairwell as he noticed the plaster dust on his doormat. Moira and Finn held their breath, muscles screaming from the strain of holding the immense weight perfectly still. Mr. Henderson grumbled, coughed his dry, rattling cough, and then, mercifully, shuffled back inside. The sound of his door clicking shut was their reprieve. They waited a full, agonising minute before slowly, painstakingly, resuming the descent.

Getting the crate out of the close and onto the pavement was a final, herculean effort. The morning air was cold and damp on their sweat-soaked faces. Pedestrians on the other side of Great Western Road hurried by under umbrellas, oblivious to the fact that two people were wrestling a Bengal tiger out of a tenement building. The tail lift on the Luton van whined in protest as it took the full weight, lifting the crate into the back of the van. Moira slammed the roller door down, the final, deafening clang sealing their success. She and Finn leaned against the side of the van, gasping for air in the drizzling rain. They had done it. It was 7:45 AM. The tiger was in the van. They had just over two hours until the inspector arrived. Finn looked at her, his expression a mixture of terror, disbelief, and a strange, wild admiration. "Okay," he panted, wiping rain and sweat from his forehead. "You got him out. I have just one question, General MacLeod. Where the bloody hell are we going?"

Moira wiped a smear of rain from her cheek with the back of her hand, leaving a streak of grime. She didn’t look at Finn. She looked at the van, this ridiculous white box that now contained the epicentre of her new life. Her voice, when it came, was as flat and grey as the morning. "We're going to IKEA."

Finn stared at her for a long, unblinking moment. The rain dripped from the end of his nose. His expensive cashmere was soaked through, clinging to his slight frame.
